content.description: Stand start from the left side of the shelf and use slab dishes, smears, and a sidepull to get going. Head up to the bulge and shelf and mantle. An uncontrolled fall might head off the initial shelf to the ground below so be mindful of your DOF. Exiting and mantling right is harder but keeps you over your pad. Exiting left would increase your fall severity.
content.protection: 1-2 pads. 2nd pad can help protect the longer fall below the shelf.
content.location: 34.71540925646328, -98.67318457136568From Dark Star head north 30 yds and east downhill. Follow the features to your right and you should arrive at Huggy Bear and Gummy Bear in the Bear's Den.From Stack Boulder, head north 200 yds and pass Dark Star by 30 yds.  Head north 30 yds and east downhill. Follow the features to your right and you should arrive at Huggy Bear and Gummy Bear in the Bear's Den.

content.description: Start sitting with a hand on both sides of the prow. Most people begin with a low left foot on the overhang and a right heel on the right side of the prow. Follow it to the top and mantle.
content.protection: 1 pad if you you feel it is necessary.

content.description: Start low in the crack on the face. Plenty of low feet to start. Follow the crack up and left and top out there.
content.location: If you're standing right in front of, and looking at Huggy Bear, this problem is 5 feet behind you.

content.description: Start on the only obvious hold (a gaston/sidepull with a tiny crimp on top). Feet are there but not obvious. The sloping arete is on but the ledge around the corner left should not be used.
content.protection: Two pads would be a good idea and a spotter is almost necessary to make the mantle safe at the top
content.location: This boulder is 10 feet above and to the left of Huggy Bear. It can most easily be reached by going over the dark star boulder cluster but going around is also an option.

content.description: There are three problems back here. Gummy Bear and Huggy Bear are both short but stout problems, and Bearly There is a fun little slab.
